text:
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.
No. 5
Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: Mrs. Olia Olson - as told to Rev. M.J. Hogan, P.P.

Present Address: Kenaston.

Pioneer Address: Kenaston - Apparently original name was Bonington changed to Kenaston soon after 1906.

Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1906

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan.)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? about ten homes - four bachelors

How many of these were bachelor's homes? four bachelors

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? once a week

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? mostly Sundays

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? We didn't wait to be invited. We stayed for meals without being asked. We knew we were welcome to share what they had. What time of the day did you go, in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.?

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? As mentioned above there was nothing very formal about meals.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?)

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? Coffee, lunch, cookies or sometimes sandwiches.

Not too much meat in those days.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? Some stayed home to look after the place and stock.

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity?

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe. We had many parties, sang, danced, visited - lunch quite plain cake and sandwiches - pork was used extensively

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? No set time - just went when we figured people were home... visited about once a week usually turnabout.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES COOPERATORS.

No. 5

Florence Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? about two houses - 200 feet or less.

How many of these were bachelor's homes? four bachelors

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? once a week mostly Sundays

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? mostly Sundays

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? We didn't wait to be invited. We didn't wait to be invited. We didn't wait to be invited. We didn't wait to be invited.

What time of the day did you go? - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

As mentioned above there was nothing very formal about meals. How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term to "make potluck" used, or was some other expression common?)

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in? octree, lunch, cookies or sometimes sandwiches.

Not too much used in those days was the phrase "look after the place?"

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to look after the place? Some stayed home to look after the place and cook.

6. Did you ever have "bees," with groups of neighbors come together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there any parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe. We had many summer dances, dark nights sang, danced, visited. Lunch quite plain cake and sandwiches.

Port was used extensively

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one house to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a month, once a month, etc.? No set time - just went when we figured people were home... visited about once a week usually.
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

They made dance for Christmas trees. The teachers arranged programs. Most people went to the school house dances.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

9. When was your first community hall built? 1920

What material was it made of? Lumber How large was it? 100'x40'

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? Village

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?)

10. When parties, dances, etc. were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend? The babies were usually put to bed on desks with quilts.

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties? They were covered with horse blankets and tied back of the school house.

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Was there card playing for a prize?

What dances were popular? Waltzes and square dances

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain. No disagreement. Those who didn't dance came to visit.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain. All accepted it
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, book sales, and other activities. Include also the school Christmas tree. Give dates.

They made dance for Christmas tree. The teachers arranged programs. Most people went to the school house dances.

How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

9. When was your first community hall built? 1920

What material was it made of? Lumber

How large was it? 11' x 10'

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? Village

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? Village

To what extent did it take the place of home or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the old school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall for town or other functions, etc.? Or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend? The babies were usually put to bed and left with quilts.

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

They were covered with horse blankets and tied back of the school house.

School houses were popular in the early days.

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Was there card playing for a prize?

What dances were popular?

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain. No disagreement.

Those who didn't dance came to visit.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain. All accepted it.
12. What attempts at formality, or "swank", do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.? About 1920 we noticed a change, but no formality still isn't any.

13. Was the chivaree known in your community? Never heard of it. Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community? Homemakers. Give the date and reason for it being organized. 1918

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community? Yes. Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many women belonged? How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district?

When was it organized?

Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
3.

12. What attempts at formality, or "snobbery," do you remember in small towns, such as those and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially informally - socially?

13. Was the chivalry known in your community? Never heard of it

Describe what you remember about chivalry, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties etc., that you remember, times of day, places, etc., and give approximate dates whether you can when these changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember being established in your community? Homemakers.

Give the date and reason for its being organized. 1918

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community? Yes

Tell when it was organized, and vital steps led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many women belonged? How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? When was it organized?

Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1924, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people?), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was centred in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? 

Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? No Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)? Drop the handkerchief, ring a rosie, girls played house and boys played ball.

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)?
4. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, and describe who belonged (that is, whom, you or people), whether it included only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district) or was centered in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

What were the common uses by organizations for raising money?

17. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? If so, give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (sandlot types, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)? Drop the handkerchief, ring a rosie, girls played house and boys played ball.

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)?
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.?  
fox and Geese; skating

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families", "Authors" or others, checkers or other games?

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain. Not too much time for games. Children and grown ups were busy. Children helped herd cattle. Breaking land was hard work. Women sewed, made soap, cured meat. The men hauled wood in Winter from as far as forty miles; water was hauled from lakes which are dried up now. There were no

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects, animals, or games in the snow? Describe. Children trapped gophers in Summer and made snow houses in Winter. There seemed to be a lot of gophers.

PICNICS AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible.1 July 1907

26. Who organized it? Village of Kenaston

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.? the whole community.

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? As far as I know Yes

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)? ball; foot races, sack races.

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups? Families and friends usually got together.

31. What did you have to eat and drink? just very plain food.

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last? in the afternoon till evening
23. Was there much time for games? Explain.

24. Did children hunt game connected with such things as buffalo, bears, birds, or other animals?

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan?

26. Who organized it?

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, or just the whole community?

28. Was the first picnic held in the community? If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?

30. What arrangements were made for eating—was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups? Families and friends usually got together.

31. What did you have to eat and drink? Just very plain food.

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last? In the afternoon till evening.
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding. An oxen wagon race... Some excitement when the oxen ran away with Steve Powell holding on grimly... They had to round up the oxen on horseback.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

What year? How long did it continue?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

1917 outdoor rink for hockey

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

1960. Curling and hockey
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

An extra wagon ride... some excitement in using the open rink... they hit up their own on harpeth creek...

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School, plantation, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drinks, when held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first year? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

What year? How long did it continue?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization (if possible) and tell something of their activities—played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centers, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hokey, curling, etc.).

1917 outdoor rink for hokey.

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

1920, Curling and hokey
40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community?
   Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic?
   Who was responsible for starting the first sports day?

   When was the sports day usually held? (what month, or any special day, such
   as May 24th or July 1st).

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known
   hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the
   names and authors if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many
   books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them?
   What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school?
   Give details and dates.

48. Was there a school library? When was it begun?
   To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to
   read at home?

49. Did parents ever use their children's school textbooks as additional reading
   material?
40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community plans? Who was responsible for starting the first sports day?

Then was the sports day usually held (what month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 4th).

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible; if not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them? What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Give details and dates.

48. Was there a school library? When was it begun? To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home?

49. Did parents ever use their children's school texts books as additional reading material?
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town?
   When was it started? Who started it?
   Is it still in existence?
   If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

   Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material?
   Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town?
   When was it started?
   Who started it?
   Is it still in existence?
   If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contains, how many people used it, where it was kept, who served as librarian,
and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to
    the west?

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain
    subscriptions and added others.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading
    material?
    Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your
    early days in the west a hardship? Explain.
MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you? Violin - still have it

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have? violins

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe. played the violin mostly, lots of singing in the home.

in the community? (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home? Old Nellies Grey Swanee River, Old Black Joe, After the Ball.

in the community?

61. Was "folk music", or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

63. Was there a band in your community? Yes When was it started? 1920 Who started it? Anton Dobesh How long did it continue?

How many were in it? 8 Who was bandmaster? Tom Hagg

What instruments were included? Drum, Saxaphone, Clarinette

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
MUSICAL ENTERPRISE.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you? Violin - still have it.

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have? Violins.

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the West? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainments in early years in the West? Describe, played the violin mostly.

In the community? (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home? Old Melodies Generally Shenee River, Old Black Joe, After the Ball.

In the community?

61. Was "folk music", or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

63. Was there a band in your community? Yes When was it started? 1920

Who started it? Anton Dobesh

How long did it continue?

How many were in it? 8

Who was bandmaster? Tom Ferg

What instruments were included? Drum, Saxophone, Clarinette

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances.

65. Is music as important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change? We still had a band in 1951. Not so much entertainment in the home.

HOBBIES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS.

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainment, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned. (Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary).
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give name and dates and places of public appearances.

65. Is music as important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change? Are we still held at board in 1921? Not so much other entertainments in the home.

HOBBIES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS.

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainments, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned.

(Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary.)
